p: As shown in recent years, many polycyclic endoperoxides, both natural and synthetic, have antimalarial effects [ 21, 22]. It is known that malaria or “swamp fever” refers to a group of transmissible infectious diseases transmitted to humans by bites of female mosquitoes belonging to the genus Anopheles, caused by parasitic protists of the genus Plasmodium, mainly P. falciparum [ 23, 24, 25]. According to the WHO World Malaria Report, at the beginning of the 21st century, the incidence ranged from 350 to 500 million cases per year, of which 1 to 3 million ended in death [ 26, 27]. In connection with these ominous data, any new sources of natural antimalarial agents are of great interest to medicine and pharmacology, as well as to the pharmaceutical industry [ 28, 29, 30].
